CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 19, 1952, pg. 4, reads: "'Mystery House?' - The lavishly appointed, ten-room alleged 'Mystery House' (center), located at 925 Bryn Mawr Road, in 'Lush Life Outer Drive' or 'Scotch and Soda Highlands' area of the reputed swank Schenley Heights District, owned and operated by Howard Spencer, former local and national track star, was raided twice within a week by Inspector James McKnight of Juvenile Court and squad on complaint of a 14-year-old girl and a 23-year-old woman. Both complaints stated they had on occasions visited 'Mystery House' for 'entertainment purposes.'  Spencer and several others were arrested and held for court. - Harris Photo."Cutline for image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 4, 1952, pg. 4, reads: "'Mystery Mansion' Case Ends - A Criminal Court jury, sitting before Judge John T. Duff, deliberated less than half an hour Tuesday before returning a 'guilty' verdict against Howard Spencer, 32-year-old Pittsburgh sportsman, on charges that he used his home (shown) at 925 Bryn Mawr Road - tabbed by the press 'mystery mansion' - as a bawdy house, engaged in pandering and contributed to the delinquency of a 15-year-old girl.  Spencer will be sentenced later this week.  Key figure in case, Frank Sneed, was killed weeks ago in Oregon by a gambler."
TitMainTitle: Brick houses, including "Mystery Mansion" in center with second floor bay window and scalloped slate roof, 925 Bryn Mawr Road, Schenley Heights
